column9: Uredinia on upper leaf surface which are brown in color and generally circular in shape
Oval and yellow lesions irregularly scattered on the leaves.
Glumes covered with blackand sooty-appearing mold and black at seed ends also embryos often shriveled and brown to black in color
Uredinia are brick red oval lesions on  true stem and spike.
Spores lying dormant in the soil or on seed germinate and infect emerging seedings.
Grain kernels replaced with brown masses of spores known as smut balls
Masses of black teliospores are produced in narrow strips just beneath the epidermis of leaves
Grain kernels replaced with solid purple-black mass of fungal hyphae called a sclerotia
Black coloured spore mass replaces a portion of the grain and the pericarp may be intact or ruptured.
Grain kernels replaced with green-brown masses of spores covered by a thin membrane
White or gray-brown powdery or cottony patches of mycelium
Spikelets appear bleached often with a pale pink tint and seeds of light weight

column8: Ballad Plus at 1 to 4 quarts/A on 7- to 14-day intervals
column9: Citron-yellow uredia (spore masses) appear in long stripes on leaves and on stems and heads
blackened appearance of mature or dead spikes
Small yellow or dark spots on the leaf which develop into yellow lesions or spots
Damping off of seedlings and diseased tissues will  permeate the soil surrounding the plant.
Water-soaked spots develop which expand and progress from gray-green to tan-white
Yellow exudate on the spikes and the spikes and necks will emerge as a distorted sticky

column8: Controlling volunteer cereals and grassy weeds
column9: Blackened chaff with stripes that have a water-soaked appearance and droplets of sticky yellowish exudate
